                AP Photo

            By 
Rachael Bade

09/28/15 10:58 PM EDT
Hill Republicans want to question the former Hillary Clinton campaign staffer who helped decide which of the former Secretary of State's emails should be kept as official government records — just days after new Clinton emails surfaced. 
The House Benghazi Committee plans to ask Heather Samuelson to testify about the process by which she sifted through Clinton’s 60,000 emails and sorted them as work-related or “personal,” POLITICO has learned. And across the Hill campus, a source said Senate Judiciary Committee Republicans also want to know more about Samuelson’s work was doing, who followed Clinton to the State Department after working on her 2008 campaign.
Story Continued Below
“I’m not exactly certain what day, but obviously she had a role in the email issue and so it’s important for us to get the facts as to what her instructions were and what her knowledge was and really what happened surrounding the email decisions — and so yes, we’ll be hearing from her,” said Rep. Susan Brooks, an Indiana Republican who sits on the Benghazi panel, on Monday.
If Samuelson does not appear willingly, the committee could decide to subpoena her, according to one Republican source familiar with the investigation.
Clinton’s former chief of staff Cheryl Mills said Samuelson was the attorney who went through each email to preliminarily decide which messages were work related and should be turned over, several sources told POLITICO last month. Samuelson has not responded to requests for comment.
Republicans are likely to ask Samuelson about what instructions she was following while combing through Clinton’s emails. Under preservation rules at federal agencies, even emails with the slightest bit of work-related information in them must be stored as public records.
The GOP hopes to question Samuelson following the latest revelation that suggest Clinton may not have turned over all her work-related email traffic.
Earlier this year, Clinton said she did not begin using her homemade email server until March of 2009, about two months after she began working at the State Department. 
But according to reports, the State Department said Friday it received copies of a January 2009 exchange from Clinton's private account with Gen. David Petraeus, correspondence that only came to light after it was forwarded to State from the department’s inspector general and the Defense Department. 
Clinton dodged questions about the matter on “Meet the Press” Sunday.
“[W]e have a very thorough review process that we conducted, and my attorneys supervised it,” Clinton said last Sunday. “They went through everything. And what we had available at the time was turned over.”
When pressed about the timeline discrepancy between when she began using the private account and the Petraeus message, Clinton added: “There was a transition period. You know, I wasn't that focused on my email account to be clear here.”
Since Clinton used a personal server rather than a State.gov account, her legal team was tasked with going through each message to decide which should be preserved and turned over to the State Department.
Mills and Clinton’s lawyer David Kendall made the ultimate decisions about what exactly was turned over, Clinton camp sources say. Her team said they then deleted the rest of the “personal” emails—but the FBI, which is investigating whether classified intelligence was ever put at risk, has recovered those documents, according to reports.
Now Republicans want to hear from Samuelson. The Benghazi committee months ago found more than a dozen other undisclosed work-related emails Clinton had not turned over after subpoenaing her ally Sid Blumenthal for any correspondence he had with Clinton that was related to Libya.
Republicans are concerned that more may have been kept from the public.
“I think it’s essential we talk to her,” said Rep. Lynn Westmoreland (R-Ga.).
 Clinton’s camp has said that they were over-inclusive in what they classified as an official document. And State has had to return some messages they say are not official. But it’s unclear exactly how they classified the information as “personal” and work related.
According to her Linked-In profile, Samuelson, who received her law degree from American University, began working for Clinton in the fall of 2002 as the assistant treasurer for her political action committee, Hill PAC, and as deputy director of compliance for Friends of Hillary.
She stayed there four years before joining Hillary Clinton for President in January 2007. For nine months she worked on compliance issues before serving as director of vetting in the campaign’s counsel’s office.
When Clinton moved to State, so did she, working for four years as senior advisor and White House liaison at the State Department from January 2009 to March 2013.
She then served as assistant counsel at the White House from then until April of 2014.
It is unclear where she is now, but a Maryland State Bar Association listing shows her address is now in Brooklyn, N.Y., which is also where Hillary for America is headquartered.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: GOP wants to hear from Clinton email screener
